segments.text: Because we've been fully integrated.
And I said, alert several of those truck units, and let's get the MP company there that furnishes an escort and convoy control.
And I said, we want to start rolling trucks out of that depot by 10 o'clock tonight.
This was then about 3.30, 4 o'clock.
And I said, I'm on my way back, and I will ride down with the first convoy and with the first contingent and check it in.
And so they said, OK, we're on our way.
So they went to work.
And by the time I got there, they were already loading the vehicles.
And we actually shipped that first evening.
We shipped 60.
10-ton trailer loads full.
So that was about 600 tons.
It was about 10 tons in those 10-ton trailer loads.
And all the ingredients to bake bread.
So... Did you get it down there by midnight?
Oh, hell yeah.
We got it there by... We started leaving the depot about 9 o'clock, 9.30.
And I went down, we went down in a contingent of...
Oh, I think 10 trucks, 10 truck units.
And with each 10 truck unit, we had one extra tractor go along in case a tractor broke down.
And we had a wrecker with each two units.
In other words, we had three wreckers for the six units, six 10 truck units.
And one, six extra tractors.
to cover, but nothing broke down, no flat tires, no nothing, it was just perfect.
We rolled through the gates, we drove up to the gate, but we were pretty close to Ryan Main.
We called on our radio and asked them to send an MP Jeep out to guide us through the proper gate they wanted us to go through.
And they did.
We were still out on the Autobahn on the call.
They did.
And we went through their first gate with our first trucks about a quarter of 11 at night.
And the last one came through the gate a little before midnight.
We put over 600 tons in LeMay.
Was he there?
Was LeMay?
He was there about 1.30.
And I was still there.
I stayed there all night.
But about 1.30, he drove in, and he was driving around, and he saw all these goddamn, of course, they'd already started loading aircraft.
Sure.
Trucks.
And they'd drive the trailer right up to the aircraft.
And they had DPs loading the airplanes down there.
We used thousands of DPs in Europe then.
And he said, my God, where did you get all this stuff?
I says, General LeMay, this is not a drop in the bucket of what we got available to.
just a little bit.
Well anyway, for the first few days, most of the stuff that was sent in to Berlin was for support of the U.S. military contingent.
And then gradually the airlift started carrying civilian supplies and things like this.
because it had to, because we flew in all the necessities for life in West Berlin.
And as it developed, it developed very shortly that the biggest tonnage problem of the airlift would be coal, black hard coal.
And to figure out how to get it into Berlin,
was really a major logistic problem.
And LeMay, the old bomber pilot and bomber commander that he is, he had idea to take B-17s

and put coal in sacks in B-17, in the bomb bays of B-17s, then fly over an area, there was a big area near Tegel, T-E-G-L, Tegel, or later another airport was built in Berlin to handle some of the traffic out of Tegel, and then take some of the load off of Tempelhof, but to fly over this big open space near Tegel,
open the bomb bays and drop this coal and then push it up and scoop it up with bulldozers and front-end loaders.
And they tried a few of it, but it just didn't work very well.
So they finally decided that they asked me one day to find out how many duffel bags there were in the stock throughout Europe.
And we came up with a figure, oh, about five million.

And they said, well, we'll send some of them up to the Ruhr so they can play around with them at those coal mines in the Ruhr on whether they can fill them readily and then load them in rail cars and ship them down to the airfield.
And we'll ship the stuff in duffel bags and then it can be unloaded easily and so forth.
And that's how it was.
And we found out that a duffel bag would make about 30 round trips before it wore out and became threadbare.
And it worked out perfectly because a loaded duffel bag of soft coal or anthracite would weigh about 120 pounds, I think.
And a DP could handle it, and they could swing them up
trucks in Berlin and then they dumped it out and shipped the empty bags back.
And they very soon decided, very soon found out that airplanes that carried coal should stay in that service because they very quickly became saturated with coal dust on the inside.
And after maybe a hundred trips with coal
they would send those aircraft back to a depot in England where they'd be thoroughly cleaned out and all the coal dust cleaned out.
I made a couple of trips up to Berlin in a coal plane.
And I was up to Berlin during the lift many, many times.
But it was the airlift during the period it operated
That's going to be hard for you to envision, but averaged about 10,000 tons a day.
I know.
I've read the statistics on that.
It's incredible.
The biggest, of course, the Germans would just hang around those airfields and look at those planes flying and look at them coming in in bad weather, my God, in fog.
Sometime you could only, you could barely see the front of your car.
Lift planes were taking off and landing and of course that's where we perfected GCA, Ground Control Approach, with radar.
It was during the Berlin hair lift.
And it was really, I think, America's finest hour to the rest of the world for them to see
with a peacetime effort to thwart a quasi wartime move that an adversary was making.
And it gained for us, I think, a tremendous, a lot of respect from the Germans and from other people in Europe.
to see the effort that was made and there were about 50 some odd lives lost, American lives lost.
Most of the lives that were lost were accidents caused by planes flying into the tails of other aircraft in the corridor, yeah.
It was so tight in the corridor
that if a pilot missed his approach into Tempelhof or to Tegel, and he missed and had to go around, he could not immediately go around and land again.
He had to go back into the return corridor, almost to a point near the city of Fulda, so they could work him back in to the corridor to Berlin.
You'd have to go back quite a few miles back in the return corridor.
Now when you went to Berlin, tell me, what were the people like during the airlift?
The Germans?
The German people?
They were amazed at the effort that American forces were doing to make the city survive.
They were very cooperative, very receptive, and most appreciative, I think, of the effort that was being made.
Was there a lot of goodwill in West Germany at this time?
Oh, yes, an awful lot.
And I know, of course, they all wanted to get as close as they could and see the operations.
But they wouldn't let the civilians come on board.
The US military would let them end up in the British zone
other air base in the British zone that we flew some coal from.
We let German newspaper people and stuff like that come in and see.
How close did you work with the British and the French on this?
Very close.
Very close.
Yeah, I made several trips up to the British command up in the British zone.
But on Easter Day they invited
the US invited, and opened the air bases for the German civilians to come in and see the operations.
And they call it the famous Easter parade, the airlift.
And as luck would have it, I guess, it was a beautiful day, a beautiful Sunday.
The weather was just beautiful.
It was warm.
And every aircraft that could fly was flying.
And that day, I think, the famous Easter parade tonnage, I think it was 12,700 or something like that tons flown that day.
And at Rhine, Maine, they estimated that about 700,000 German civilians crowded as close as they would let them in on that airfield to watch the airplanes coming.
There was an airplane in that corridor every three minutes.
Every three minutes behind one another.
Tell me about Curtis LeMay.
What kind of person was he?
He was a, he was a, I never worked for him, but of course I worked around him.
He was a, he was a real great guy and a very, a very dedicated guy.
and a real grassroots American patriot, I guess you would say.
And LeMay is, you know, is about like Patton.
I think guys like that probably are ordained or born to exist at the time they did exist.
I really think Patton, I believe, Patton believed that he had been reincarnated, and I really believe he had.

I think he did fight with Hannibal like he said he did in North Africa when he, after the Battle of Kasserine Pass, he said, I remember right over this hill, we fought this so-and-so, and sure enough, he walked over there and he said it was right there.
And the other officers looked at him, they thought he was crazy.
But I think guys like Patton and LeMay are probably people like that.
But anyway, the Berlin Airlift, I really believe, was one of America's finest hours.
Now, some people will disagree with that.
They will think that we showed weakness
by resorting to the airlift.
I don't really think so.
I think we probably could have maybe made a show of force and pushed a convoy up there with armored vehicles in the lead and fought our way into Berlin.
But I think what we did
so amazed and so humiliated the Russians that I think it was a bigger defeat for them than if we had run over them with tanks.
I think it was one of America's finest hours.
It was really quite an operation.
And there's a little side to the airlift that's never been told.
I'll tell you, and if I'm ever called up about it, I'll deny it.
But early in the airlift, one of the real headaches was that, how in the hell are we going to get a little gasoline up there, and the liquid fuels?
Not only for the military contingent, but for the civilian population.
The British had a few tanker planes up in their zone that they had used during World War II.
We didn't have any tanker planes in Europe at that time.
So a few tanker loads using those British tanker planes were flown up there.

Then I think it was an American civilian representative, I believe it was Shell Oil, said that he's pretty sure we could, by using some of the canals and rivers and so forth in the northern part of Germany from Hamburg, we could work our way into Berlin with barges.
liquid fuel and he believes that by bribing the right Russian officers when we got to the Russian zone we could get in barge loads of liquid fuel gasoline and diesel and so forth.
He was given the go-ahead to do that to make those arrangements.
Those arrangements were made and a lot I think most of
was taken in by handing over to some Russian officers or Russian commanders, gold marks or gold francs or whatever.
Whatever the bribe was made in, it was made in gold, so I'm told.
But a lot of, most of the liquid fuel, because I know after the first two or three weeks, there was no more said about the tanker planes.
And every time I went to Berlin, I knew nothing about it after that.
And every time I went to Berlin, we had plenty of fuel up there.
And I know I made a couple of comments about it.
I said, well, Shell's able to get it up here.
And it's one of those things we didn't talk about.
The same sort of thing happened in Southeast Asia during the war with rubber.

after the Japs swarmed all over a certain part of Southeast Asia, the word was put out that for every little sandpan or every little boatload of rubber that arrived in Australia, one or two ports in Australia, so much in gold would be paid.
And not a big tonnage of rubber, but quite a flow of rubber.
crude rubber came into Australia the same way.
Did you leave after the Berlin?
After the airlift?
Shortly after that I was transferred back to the States.
Back to Washington?
Yeah, back to Washington.
I didn't come back until 50.
Yeah, but it wasn't too long because the airlift was on about a year.
Okay, it was during this time, during the airlift, that Truman integrated the Armed Forces.
What was your opinion on that?

Well, I thought it was high time really that they'd be integrated because like those truck companies up there in Geeson and other areas and I know I had had some dealings with some black officers and all of them that I knew were, you know, very capable and very likable.
And there was one, there was a black chaplain there in Geesen that my kids just loved and I loved the guy.
And I later, we later ran into him in Japan and we've seen him several times since then and he was a wonderful, wonderful guy.
So I think Truman made a very smart move doing that.
Was there any grumbling?
Yes, there was quite a bit.
But I think it really was minimal.
I think it was done with the minimum of problems, really.
Did you have any problems at your command?
No, none at all.
Were blacks moving into your command then after the integration order?
Yes.
The quasi-problem I had with integration was in Japan.
When was that?
54, 55, when I commanded all of the petroleum facilities in the Western Pacific.
Everything in Japan, and I had operational control over the petroleum
and on Okinawa.
And these were mostly facilities that we had taken over from the Japanese.
They were mostly underground facilities.
And this was a joint operation.
We had all the fuel for the Navy and the Air Force and the Army and everybody out there west of Hawaii.
I had a couple of black officers at some of my terminals.
My command stretched for 1,500 miles.
I had terminals on Hokkaido and up in the north and on Kyushu and way in the southernmost major island in Japan.
I had a couple of black officers
to a beautiful blonde-headed German girl who was the daughter of the former mayor of Berlin.
He had married her when he was stationed in Berlin.
And he was assigned to my petroleum storage facility and depot in Sasebo.
There was a little bit of a problem there.
have too many officers ourselves at that depot of about 15.
But in the Sasebo itself, there was other military units.
And there was a couple of minor incidents at the club, like dances at the club by this officer.
It was a nice looking guy.
Wanted to dance with other white officers' wives.
And of course, other white guys danced with his wife, his white wife.
So, but nothing real serious.
And we had another case like that at a storage facility near Tokyo.
But those things, they only happened once or twice.
And most of the time, the black officer,
went out of his way not to force himself to dance with or be put in a position where he would have to dance with a white officer's wife.
But I think by and large, I think integration in the services certainly went a lot smoother than it has in other parts of our economy.
in our daily life.
Okay, let's turn to Korea.
Of course in 1950 North Korea invaded South Korea, and America joined in the U.S. or U.N. force.
What role did you have?
I had very little direct role.
I made several trips to Korea, and
During the, I was not there at all during the fighting.
Not at all.
We have a, there's an Aggie who became a flag officer, Ray Murray.
Did you interview him?
Where does he live?
He's a Marine.
Marine.
He's a major general.
Ray Murray.
He does not live in Texas though, does he?
That's why I haven't interviewed him.
He commanded the Marine Regiment that fought the Chinese at the Chosin Reservoir.
No kidding.
Oh, yeah.
Ray is a... And he was a football player.
In fact, he kept me from lettering one year at the end.
Ray was an in.
A heck of a nice guy.
Ray Murray.
Very, very distinguished guy.
But I...
I saw some service at Pusan and at Inchon after the Korean fighting.
I spent about 60 days at Pusan and Inchon, but I had very little direct contact in the Korean operations.
There's one thing that I want to tell you about that is not written up anywhere in any bibliography of mine.
But I feel very deeply about it.
It affected me.
It affected the rank that I was able to achieve.
It kept me from getting another star.
I know that particularly.
And if ever anybody really died for a good cause, I think I did.
Right after I came back from Germany, I was assigned briefly, and that's about a year, in the assignment branch for military personnel, for officers and warrant officers.
And during.
So you were chief military personnel for Quartermaster General?
Yeah, yeah.
OK. Yeah.
For about a year and a half.
This was about 1949?
And you were a full colonel at the time?
No, still a lieutenant colonel.
Because I had been demoted prior to the war.
I was still a lieutenant colonel.
But it was a colonel's billet.
And I just loved it.
My God, I loved the personnel.
And I was there when Korea broke out and felt it had the responsibility for the recall of officers to active duty.
deferred and guys wanted compassionate deferment.
I had one officer's wife offered to go to bed with me if I did not call her husband to duty.
Yeah, a socialite in New York wanted me to meet her at the New Yorker Hotel and everything to keep him from coming to duty.
And, but the biggest thing, the thing that I'm most proud of in my whole military career

During the course of this minute review of a lot of files, a civilian lady that had been a fixture in military personnel for 30 years, she was not an old woman either, she was a single gal, quite a swinger in her own right, but she came in to me one day and showed me a file.
where there was a major discrepancy in this officer's file pertaining to his integration into the regular army.
At the time... Was she in the military herself?
No, no.
She was a civilian personnel.
Worked in military personnel and had worked in military personnel all these years.

When the people were integrated, when I was integrated, and everybody was integrated into the Army, we had to fill out an exhaustive personal history statement about all our background, all our education.
And one of the prime prerequisites, you should have at least two years of college.
The military wanted the applicants to have at least two years of college.
Some guys were integrated that didn't have two years.
I think nobody was integrated that didn't have any college experience.
So people filled out and they were, they provided transcripts of their data to substantiate it and so forth.
And a lot of other personal history and so forth and so on.
The FBI and the CID checked on all of these things and rendered a report to the Department of the Army on what they found and so forth.
Well, in this discrepancy that this lady brought in to me one evening and showed to me, we were in the process of
screening some officers to go to a school, to go to a higher school like the Command and General Staff College or something like that.

She showed me in his integration thing where he claimed that he had graduated from the University of Cincinnati and that the FBI in their background investigation of everybody that was integrated reported in just a very terse statement

that the registrar at the University of Cincinnati said that there was nothing in the records of the university to show that this individual had ever been a full-time or part-time student at the University of Cincinnati.
And here he had reported that he had gone four years and had graduated
And there was a photostat, a black, white photostat type copy of a transcript to that effect in his file that she showed me, that we looked at.
And she said, do you know who this individual is?
And I said, no.
And it was George Gordon, last name.
I won't even tell you the last name on tape.
He was a very close relative to Dwight D. Eisenhower.
And I said, well, that is a problem, isn't it?
And I said, Josephine, why hasn't something been done about this before?
Here it's been in the file, and I know before that,
A lot of these discrepancies had come to light, and action had been taken, and guys had been kicked out, or when their discrepancy was shown to them, they had resigned.
They give them that option.
I said, why hasn't something been done about this?
She looked at me, and she said, your guess is as good as mine.
And I said, did my predecessor know about this discrepancy in this job?
And she said, I think he did.
you wouldn't have said it that way.
And I said, Josephine, how many more major discrepancies
do we have, and before, and I said, before we do anything about it, I'm gonna make a check myself on this.
I said, how many major discrepancies like this do we think are still lying in these files and that we don't know about?
She said, Colonel, I think there's at least 100 or 200 major discrepancies.
Where they just outright lie in false statements about their integration.
When damn good officers
that didn't even apply or that were turned down began just because they had told the truth about theirs.
And she said, I think there's at least 200.
And I said, I can appreciate it.
Somebody said he had 40 hours and maybe he only had 32 hours.
To me, that's a minor, it's a minor discrepancy.
But to say he graduated
When the registrar said he'd never registered, I said, that's major.
So I said, I'm going to do some checking on this myself.
I called the University of Cincinnati, talked to the registrar, and told him who I was.
And I said, I'm looking at a background report by the FBI on, I won't tell you the name yet, when you turn it off,
George Gordon Moore, married to Dwight D. Eisenhower's wife's sister, married to Mamie's sister.
What rank was he?
Huh?
What rank was he?
Lieutenant Colonel.
He had been a colonel and demoted.
He was an integrated officer.
So I said, this is a pretty hot potato, and I told him why.
He said, my goodness, that is hot, isn't it?
And I said, your university has said in this FBI background report that he'd never been a student.
I said, would you please check that again, just to be sure that he's never was a full-time.
Number one, that he was not a graduate.
Number one, he was never a full-time student, and so forth.
And he said, we sure will, and we'll get back to you.
Well, about three or four days later,
The president of the university called me, Cincinnati University, and said, we've really done some soul searching on what you reported to the registrar.
And he said, we are prepared to state, and I will send you a telegram or a letter, whichever you think is appropriate.
We are prepared to say that so far as we know, he's never even been a visitor on this campus.
He is, number one, not a graduate.
Number two, he's never been registered, either as full-time or part-time or evening or continuing education or anything.
Never in any form.
We've even checked the membership records of fraternities during the time period that he said he was here.
We've checked other dormitory records, and his name does not appear.
And we said, we think if he has a transcript, it's a fabrication.
And I said, would you just send me a letter and confirm what you've told me?
He said, I'll do that.
I'll dictate it when I hang up.
So I took his file and walked upstairs and showed it to my boss, the major general.
I said, we really got a hot one on our hands here.
And he said, my god, it is, isn't it?
And I said, I think there's some more like it, but there won't any be as big as this.
So he said, well, why don't you make a check and let's see how many more we've got.
Meanwhile, let me do some talking to some of the guys over in the staff and over in the G1 and the general staff and see what we ought to do.
And I said, I know what we ought to do.
I ought to confront him and tell him what's his reply to this, what's his explanation of it, and tell him he has two alternatives.
I'll take his resignation right now, or he can fight it, and we can put him before a board to show cause why he should not be separated.
And he said, my God, that would be tough.
And I said, but I know that we've got to do it.
And I said, there's just no ifs, ands, and buts about it.
So.
Who was your commanding general?
A fellow named Fellman, Herman Fellman.
And a gutty little guy.
And he was mixed up at one time in the, in the, he was drawn into that Harry Vaughn.
Oh, yeah.
The Truman.
Sure, the Harry Vaughn Truman episode.
Yeah, yeah.
with Vaughn and so forth.
Very courageous little guy.
And I said, well, I'm going to have the people work through all, go through 9,000 odd files that we've got here on integrated officers and see how many major.
Well, we did that.
And it took about a week to do that.
In the meantime, I'd gotten the confirmation from the president.
We came up with 89
major discrepancy filed, 89.
Out of the 89, there were about 12 that we... 89 out of 9,000?
Yeah.
Out of the 89, there were about 12 that we excused because we believed they were just oversights or something.
And we called, I called each of those 12 up
And I said, is this true or that true?
And then I wrote a memo for the record and put them in their files and saying, these discrepancies have been resolved and the matter is closed.
The other 70-odd, we started bringing them in and telling them, confronting them with it, and saying, you have this option.
You can resign right now.
We'll give you.
You can dictate your resignation to my secretary and we'll separate you today or tomorrow at Fort Myer and that's all there is to it.
Nothing will happen.
If we take board action and you are removed from the services,
It will be kind of a neuter removal.
You will be without honor and without dishonor.
You will not get any veterans benefits or anything.
And I said, your best way is to resign.
Well, out of the 75, about 69 of them did that.
They just resigned.
And one of the guys, one of the 79,
While he was sitting there, he had two Purple Hearts.
He had his ribbons all on.
And he had one other combat decoration that I knew that he didn't have.
Anyway, I called Josephine in.
going to dictate his resignation.
I said, Josephine, I don't think he's entitled to those decorations.
And I said, make a quick check in this file and call the AG, the AG's Decorations Office, because they've got all those awards.
This was a, oh Christ, a DSC, a Distinguished Service Cross.
And I said, call them and see if he was awarded.
And I don't think he ever was.
I'm positive he's not.
And she came back in before he even came back in the office.
She came back in about 20 minutes and said, the AG says, number one, he does not, he's not entitled to the Purple Heart.
And he's not entitled to the DSC.
And he's also the only awards, the only awards
So when he came back in, I saw that he had about four ribbons that he was wearing that he was not entitled to.
And I just asked him about it right then and there.
I said, you're wearing a combat award there that most of them that were awarded were not given to the recipients, but were given to their spouses or their sons or daughters.
And I said, why in the hell are you wearing that?
Well, the guy started to break down, and he said, well, I just wanted to look like a big shot.
Jeez.
So I said, well, I said, you know, this really, it's a felony for you to wear this on a military uniform.
And I said, if you weren't resigning, I would personally prefer charges against you on that.
What do you say to that?
Oh, he just didn't have anything to say.
He just started to break down and everything.
But he resigned and we separated him.
We had him separated the next day at Fort Myers about 2 or 3 o'clock in the afternoon.
Well, anyway, we got down to Gordy after I'd
So he was on duty in Washington, and I called him.
I had known him slightly.
And I said, Gordy, would you come over?
I've got a couple of matters I want to talk to you about.
So he came over, and I just went right to the point.
Was the commanding general there, too?
No, no.
I confronted him myself.
He told me to go ahead and bring him in.
So I did.
And I said, this is a pretty serious matter.
And I said, it's doubly serious because of your relationship to General Eisenhower.
And I said, you don't have many options that are very pleasant for you under these circumstances because we verified.
But first I asked him if he had any explanation of it.
And he said, no, I don't have any explanation that I want to talk about.
So when I- Did he admit that he didn't go there?
No, he didn't admit anything, that he didn't go or anything, or that he did go.
So when I got all through, I said, you can resign right now, no problem.
You'll be a veteran, and you can resign with honor and everything.
And if we kick you out, it'll be without honor and without dishonor, if you determine to fight it.
He hesitated a little bit and then he looked me right in the eye and he says, we will fight it.
He used the expression, we will fight it.
And I said, okay, that's fine if that's your decision.
I said, think about it because tomorrow we'll process the papers to G1, Department of the Army.
The action won't be taken at this level, it'll be taken at the Pentagon level of G1.
So as soon as he left, I went up and told the boss.
I said, well, the phones are probably going to be ringing.
But he said, well, I'll tell you.
I've talked.
He told me.
I knew who the G1 was at that time.
Ted Brooks, General Brooks.
He said, I've talked to Ted Brooks.
And Ted said, god damn, bow your neck and let's purge it.
Let's purge ourselves if he's guilty.
So we prepared what case we had and the evidence we had, and we sent it forward in about two, three days.
They and G1 spent, oh, several weeks preparing and verifying and getting more evidence and more statements out of the president at the university.
And even we're going to ask him to come down and testify at the board hearing.
And...
The board met to make a long story short and about a month or six weeks after and kicked him out.
Kicked him out, yes sir.
Well shortly after that I was ordered to the Army War College and at Carlisle, which was an honor to be nominated to go to the War College.
And while I was at the War College I got a call
very well.
And he said, and he had been drinking, I know, he said,
